Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Teaching to Learn - Peer Learning Using Smart Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Peer learning can provide students with an engaging learning environment that nurtures development of higher-order cognitive skills needed by engineers for innovation. This collaborative project led by the University of Oklahoma Norman Campus with partners from Tuskegee University and the Pennsylvania State University, University Park is using mobile smart devices to facilitate peer learning. Open ended problem solving ability is one key student outcome being enhanced by this project. In the Teaching to Learn (TeatoL) environment participants serve as both teacher and learner and will collectively learn from each other's experiences. The project is developing new understanding in how students (a) understand their own cognitive processes, (b) respond to peer teaching and learning, (c) can develop peer critique and reflection, (d) use mobile devices and social networks to enhance learning. In addition the project will develop a better understanding of how "flat" classrooms impact learning, and the impact of peer learning on underrepresented STEM students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The factors that influence the transfer of knowledge through discussion, communication and articulation of ideas in online peer-to-peer learning environment are not well studied in an engineering education context. In this study, we present a technology assisted flat learning environment, Teaching to Learn (TeatoL) which involves collaborative learning within a team (intra-team) as well as cooperative learning across teams (inter-teams) and analyze the contributions of peer evaluation and feedback to the measured learning gains. In order to understand the effectiveness of technology-enabled flat learning environments, as well as the potential implementation difficulties, we implemented the Teatol system to open engineering design problems at University of Oklahoma, Tuskegee University and Pennsylvania State University. Peer learning in a technology assisted flat learning environment demonstrated to improve student learning.

Intellectual Merit:

Instruction modes need to allow students to grow as critical thinkers with proficiency in learning, and in creative problem solving for increasingly complex and uncertain engineering environments. We implemented TeatoL in a classroom of 90+ students, where all participants have dual roles as students and instructors. Within TeatoL, we integrated and expanded proven concepts, specifically peer-to-peer knowledge exchange facilitated by technology, in order to enhance the ability of engineering graduates to tackle open-ended real life problems in manufacturing. The main findings of this work are:

  • We determined that student generated instructional material content and their qualities facilitate peer-to-peer information exchange in an online flat learning environment.
  • Correlation study between number of in-depth comments and learning gains of all topics, showed a significant correlation and a dependency on the level of knowledge on the topic for the learning community (class) and the number of meaningful comments provided by their peers. Additionally, students provided more comments on the topics in which they had more knowledge and better understanding.
  • A negative relation was seen between quality of peer generated content and the number of in-depth comments received. We conclude that the peer reviewers provide more specific in-depth comments for content poor videos. Meaningful comments have shown to help students in content poor groups to have higher learning gain than the students in content rich and average groups. This study shows that students provide more superficial comments when they review videos with good/average content but provide more in-depth comments on their peers’ misunderstanding and misconceptions, when they review videos with poor content.
  • Although our study concluded that receiving meaningful comments from peers is a dominant mode of learning, students believed they learned more from reviewing/commenting on peers’ work. One student in TeatoL explained his/her experience while reviewing his peers’ work: “By reviewing other students work, I was able to compare my own with theirs and in turn develop a more sufficient process to solve or analyze an issue. By commenting, I basically recalled and scrutinized my own problems and realized what flaws I had if any”.  Students explained that reviewing others’ work helped them reflect and compare their own design.
  • Well-designed peer learning environments for online courses can enhance student learning through providing meaningful peer-to-peer knowledge exchange. Meaningful peer-to-peer learning helps develop virtual learning community to provide a richer learning experience for students in online and MOOCs (Massive Online Open Courses).
